content.question: The base of a solid is the region in the first quadrant bounded by the graph of <math alttext="y equals, 2 minus, two thirds x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>−</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></mfrac><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and the <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>- and <math alttext="y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>y</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-axes for <math alttext="0 less than or equal to x, less than or equal to 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. For the solid, each cross section perpendicular to the <math alttext="y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>y</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-axis is a rectangle whose height is five times its width in the <math alttext="x y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mi>y</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-plane. What is the volume of the solid?

topic.text: 8.7: Volumes with Cross Sections - Squares and Rectangles

skill.text: Skill 3.D: Apply an appropriate mathematical definition, theorem, or test.
